segments.en: Numbered Discourses 8
1. Love
6. Worldly Conditions (2nd)

segments.pli: “Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti, loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati.
segments.en: “Mendicants, the eight worldly conditions revolve around the world, and the world revolves around the eight worldly conditions.
What eight?

segments.pli: Lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṃsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca.
segments.en: Gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.

segments.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti, loko ca ime aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati.
segments.en: These eight worldly conditions revolve around the world, and the world revolves around these eight worldly conditions.

segments.pli: Assutavato, bhikkhave, puthujjanassa uppajjati lābhopi alābhopi yasopi ayasopi nindāpi pasaṃsāpi sukhampi dukkhampi.
segments.en: An uneducated ordinary person encounters gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, and pleasure and pain.

segments.pli: Sutavatopi, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa uppajjati lābhopi alābhopi yasopi ayasopi nindāpi pasaṃsāpi sukhampi dukkhampi.
segments.en: And so does an educated noble disciple.

segments.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ko viseso ko adhippayāso kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanenā”ti?
segments.en: What, then, is the difference between an ordinary uneducated person and an educated noble disciple?”

segments.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
segments.en: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

segments.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:
“Mendicants, an uneducated ordinary person encounters gain.
They don’t reflect:
‘I’ve encountered this gain.

segments.pli: so ca kho anicco dukkho vipariṇāmadhammo’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
segments.en: It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They don’t truly understand it.
They encounter loss …
fame …
disgrace …
praise …
blame …
pleasure …
pain.
They don’t reflect:
‘I’ve encountered this pain.

segments.pli: tañca kho aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhamman’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
segments.en: It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They don’t truly understand it.

segments.pli: Tassa lābhopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, alābhopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, yasopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, ayasopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, nindāpi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, pasaṃsāpi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, sukhampi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, dukkhampi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: So gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, and pleasure and pain occupy their mind.

segments.pli: So uppannaṃ lābhaṃ anurujjhati, alābhe paṭivirujjhati;
segments.en: They favor gain and oppose loss.
They favor fame and oppose disgrace.
They favor praise and oppose blame.
They favor pleasure and oppose pain.

segments.pli: So evaṃ anurodhavirodhasamāpanno na parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
segments.en: Being so full of favoring and opposing, they’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

segments.pli: Sutavato ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa uppajjati lābho.
segments.en: An educated noble disciple encounters gain.
They reflect:
‘I’ve encountered this gain.

segments.pli: so ca kho anicco dukkho vipariṇāmadhammo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
segments.en: It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They truly understand it.
They encounter loss …
fame …
disgrace …
praise …
blame …
pleasure …
pain.
They reflect:
‘I’ve encountered this pain.

segments.pli: tañca kho aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhamman’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
segments.en: It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They truly understand it.

segments.pli: Tassa lābhopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, alābhopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, yasopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, ayasopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, nindāpi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, pasaṃsāpi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, sukhampi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, dukkhampi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: So gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, and pleasure and pain don’t occupy their mind.

segments.pli: So uppannaṃ lābhaṃ nānurujjhati, alābhe nappaṭivirujjhati;
segments.en: They don’t favor gain or oppose loss.
They don’t favor fame or oppose disgrace.
They don’t favor praise or oppose blame.
They don’t favor pleasure or oppose pain.

segments.pli: So evaṃ anurodhavirodhavippahīno parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
segments.en: Having given up favoring and opposing, they’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
They’re freed from suffering, I say.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, viseso ayaṃ adhippayāso idaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanenāti.
segments.en: This is the difference between an educated noble disciple and an uneducated ordinary person.
Gain and loss, fame and disgrace,
praise and blame, and pleasure and pain.
These qualities among people are impermanent,
transient, and perishable.
A clever and mindful person knows these things,
seeing that they’re perishable.
Desirable things don’t disturb their mind,
nor are they repelled by the undesirable.
Both favoring and opposing
are cleared and ended, they are no more.
Knowing the stainless, sorrowless state,
they understand rightly, going beyond rebirth.”
